bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 30, 1940

div1.p: This letter contains Truby's recollections of the Yellow Fever Commission work and excerpts of his own [then incomplete] history of the Yellow Fever Commission - concerning Jesse W. Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 30, 1940
div1.p:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
July 30, 1940 Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:

Upon my return to San Francisco I found your letter of the
24th awaiting me, so I immediately went to work and had a few extracts
of my article pertaining to Dr. Lazear typed for your information. I
am sending a copy to General Kean and if he agrees that there is no
objection to releasing this information, I shall be glad to authorize
you to quote it in your address at the dedication of the Lazear
Memorial.

I shall be interested to get your reaction to the extracts
from my article. Of course, the story is a chronological review of
events as they happened and extracts about Lazear may seem to be dis-
connected. However, you can readily select the parts that fit in
your story. When your paper is ready to review, I shall be very glad
indeed to go over it and make comments as you suggested in your first
letter.

I was interested to know about Dr. Finlay's son and the book
he is writing. Poor old Finlay did not have a scientific mind but was
a very successful general practitioner. I knew him very well.

Very sincerely yours,
ALBERT E. TRUBY
Brigadier General, Med. Dept., USA
Retired
2. Incls.

General Kean was our Chief Surgeon
of the department in which Camp Columbia
was located. He and Leonard Wood, did
more to make Reed's work successful than any
other persons on Both were close friends of Reed's.
Kean is modest, but I think he distructs his
memory in recent years. He is a master of English
and has written much, and I hope he has recorded
some of his observations in Cuba-
(Over)

Ac
T

I am inclosing a photostat copy of a letter from Walter Reed
which describes his first experimental case-
(Kissinger) I have presented the original
to the Surgeon General's Library in Washington.
I had left him a few days erlier and he
knew how much I was interested in his work
His discription of Kissinger's case is the first
written account of the first experimental case of
Yellow Fever. You will note that the description
is almost identical with that of the published
report of the case several weeks later.

Extracts from the manuscript of an article (not yet published) by
Brigadier General Albert E. Truby, U. S. Army, Retired, on his experiences
and observations in Cuba (1898-1902) with especial reference to Yellow Fever
and the work of Walter Reed and the members of his board in the study of the
etiology of that disease. At that time Truby was a 1st Lieutenant in the
Medical Corps, U. S. Army. He was in command of the hospital at Columbia
Barracks at the time of Dr. Lazear's death and during much of the time the
Reed Board was conducting experiments at that station. All cases with fever
were admitted there, and, when a diagnosis was made, transfer to proper ward
was accomplished. We had a small laboratory, but no one thoroughly qualified
to operate it. Kramer and I both worked there on doubtful or special cases.

The Headquarters Department of Pinar del Rio, in which Camp Columbia was
located, was but a short distance from the camp hospital. General Fitzhue
Lee was in command and Major J. R. Kean was our Chief Surgeon. Kean was active,
energetic, and always willing and anxious to help. When I explained the need
for a full time laboratory man he promptly took steps to get a competent officer
for that work. There was a long delay as no specialist in that work was avail-
able in Cuba, but in February, 1900, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear arrived from the States
under War Department orders, and took charge of the laboratory. There was much
work to be done. Lazear did it promptly and efficiently. He also had much time
for special research work, with especial reference to Yellow Fever, and he
utilized it fully. Lazear soon became one of the most respected and efficient
members of our staff. He was always courteous and agreeable and went about his
work in our laboratory with enthusiasn. Every member of the staff was fond of
Lazear and when Reed came, he found in Lazear a real friend and loyal supporter,
also the ideal man for the board's work with mosquitoes. As will be seen later,
Lazear, working entirely alone, produced the first experimental cases of Yellow
Fever in human subjects (Carroll, “X Y”, and probably in himself). Besides
being a member of the Reed Board, Lazear continued as our laboratory chief until
his death.

Lazear was placed by Reed in full charge of the mosquito work. He had
had more experience in entomology than the other members and his selection for
this duty was fortunate.

On October 1, 1900, Major Reed returned from his trip to the United States.
He was terribly depressed at Lazear's death, not only because of his attachment
and high regard for Lazear, but also because this efficient assistant, having
all but proved “the theory” was no longer present to help finish the work
required to satisfy the medical world that the mosquito was the culprit. Age
long scientific investigations had up until now been fruitless and even Dr.
Finlay's extensive experiments with infected mosquitoes had failed completely.
Lazear was the only member of the board who was experienced in entomology and
who had given much time to the study of mosquitoes both in the United States
- 1 -
2
and in Italy. Reed realized at once how much he needed Lazear's help at that
time.

We all congregated to greet Reed and he was most anxious to get first hand
information about Lazear, and his mosquito work. I then turned over to him the
note book and other papers found in Lazear's quarters. He lost no time in
getting to his laboratory where Lazear's efficient assistant, Hospital Steward
Neate, showed him a complete history of all of Lazear's infected mosquitoes
and told him all he knew about Lazear's work in the laboratory. With this in-
formation and the data contained in the note book, Reed began his work of find-
ing out exactly what Lazear had done. It took some time to connect the data
from the book with the laboratory records, but eventually he was satisfied and
then he prepared the data which were published in Table III of the board's
“Preliminary Note” on the Aetiology of Yellow Fever. Table III gives Lazear's
results of “Inoculation of non-immune individuals through the bite of a mosquito
(Culex Fasciatus). Practically all of the data for this table came from the
precious little note book which Lazear had so carefully kept in his own posses-
sion. During his illness he left no message with us for Reed. From this I feel
sure that he fully expected to recover. He had been in perfect health, was only
34 years old, and from his extensive observation of Yellow Fever cases he no
doubt concluded that the chances were all in his favor. He saw Carroll, who was
46 and not a robust man, recovering, and he knew of the splendid record Dr. Ames
had made in the treatment of cases in our hospital. I know that Ames felt that
if Lazear had reported his illness promptly instead of working the first two days,
the case might have been a mild one.

(after studying the case of “XY” and deciding that it must have been due)
to Lazear's mosquitoes

Reed then took up the other two cases (Carroll and Lazear). In both of
them he could not be sure of the source of the infection as they had been in
infected areas almost daily, before and after they had been bitten by Lazear's
laboratory mosquitoes. However, they strongly supported “the theory”. Both of
them had been bitten by mosquitoes and had developed the disease, within the
normal incubation period. Carroll had certainly been bitten by an infected
mosquito and the same mosquito had bitten X.Y. who had promptly developed Yellow
Fever. But how about Lazear? Had he also been bitten by the same infected
mosquitoes? Reed thought that he had. He was not sure and he was much troubled
as to what he should say about it in the “Preliminary Note”. I have a distinct
recollection that there were some entries in Lazear's note book, which Reed
thought were entered about mosquitoes which Lazear had applied to himself. Un-
fortunately this important note book has mysteriously disappeared according to
information to this effect given me by General Kean or General Ireland. Carroll,
I think, had charge of this historical document after Reed's death. Reed was
rather cautious in discussing this aspect of Lazear's case, but he did confide
in Kean and me and probably discussed it with Carroll and Agramonte. He felt
that when Lazear was taken sick he thought very seriously about the future of his
family in case of his death. Would his life insurance become forfeited if it
became known that he had deliberately infected himself with a fatal disease?
Was this the reason for Lazear's incomplete entries in the note book about himself
and was this why he told Gorgas and Carroll the story about his having been bitten
- 2-
3
by a mosquito at Las Animas Hospital? Reed felt that it was. On the other
hand he was just as confident that Lazear would not knowingly let any mosquito
bite him at a Yellow Fever hospital. Lazear was a competent scientific in-
vestigator, who having already produced two cases of Yellow Fever (Carroll and
X.Y.) certainly would not let a mongrel mosquito bite him. He was after
information of tremendous importance and the only way to get it was to be
bitten by one of his own thoroughbred “birds” which had been hatched and in-
fected under his own supervision, and which had a well known pedigree. There
was no way to prove this viewpoint and so the “Preliminary Note” simply gave
the story of the supposed infection by a mosquito at Las Animas Hospital.
While it weakened the report to be unable to definitely fix the source of the
infection, Reed, in his own mind, felt sure that Lazear's case fully supported
his conclusions that X.Y's case was a bona-fide experimental case and that the
mosquitoes from the laboratory had transmitted Yellow Fever in both instances.
This viewpoint also strengthened the probability that the source of infection
in Carroll's case was the one laboratory mosquito which Lazear had placed upon
him and not caused by Carroll's visits to Havana and Las Animas Hospital.

Carroll in his Galveston address tells of Lazear's statement to him, -
“Dr. Lazear was applying mosquitoes, as usual, late in the afternoon, to
patients in the Yellow Fever hospital, known as Las Animas, and while thus
engaged a mosquito alighted upon his hand. He allowed it to take its fill, and
concluded it was one of the common Culex mosquitoes which were present in the
hospital in large numbers. So little importance did he attach to the incident
that he made no note of it, and related the incident to me when first taken
sick, five days afterward.” (Lazear and Carroll were both sick at the time in
the same hospital tent ward, under Dr. Ames' care).

In this same connection, I wish to record a discussion I had with my
esteemed friend, the late Dr. Henry R. Carter. I was calling on him at his
residence in Washington, D.C., in March, 1922. He was then writing a book on
the “History of Yellow Fever” and he was interested in what I might be able to
tell him about this particular matter. He wanted to show me a letter from
Gorgas to Mrs. Gorgas written during Lazear's illness, or just after his death,
but could not find it. A few days later I received a letter from him (Which
I still have) quoting from the Gorgas letter as follows: “Lazear told me that
he saw a mosquito, which he believed to have been the one they are investigat-
ing, on his hand at Las Animas Hospital and he let him bite as long as he
wanted to.” So far as I know these are the only statements made by Lazear
during his illness about the source of his infection. Was he withholding
facts in order to protect his dear ones at this critical moment? What do you
think?
Dr. Lazear's Funeral.

Friends from the Post, officers from Department Headquarters, including
Major Kean, and the entire medical personnel of the hospital were present at
the funeral. As the cemetery was only a few hundred yards from the hospital
on the road to La Playa everyone except the nurses walked. We were able to
- 3 -
4
transport the latter in ambulances. Officers, enlisted men, and nurses
were all in white uniforms. Carroll, who was still sick, was unable to
attend the funeral. Full military honors were accorded and it was a
spontaneous demonstration of affection for our lamented friend and co-
worker, Jesse W. Lazear.

Reed, in his Baltimore address, April, 1901, speaking of Lazear's
service at Columbia Barracks, said, “During a service of less than one
year in Cuba he won the good will and respect of his brother officers
and the affection of his immediate associates. Almost at the beginning
of what promised to be a life full of usefulness and good works he was
suddenly stricken and, dying, added one more name to that imperishable
roll of honor to which none others belong than martyrs to the cause of
humanity.”
